NEWS-LETTER

Snyder Announces SC
Plans, Frosh Elections
Gil Snyder, president of the Student Council, has announced that
the freshman assembly originally
scheduled for Wednesday afternoon has been changed to Tuesday at four; but he emphasized
that the elections will still take
place on Thursday.
Snyder urges all freshmen to
attend the assembly, for the candidates running for offices will be
introduced at that time. They will
give short speeches.
Beside running the freshman
elections, the Student Council has
many other plans for the coming
year. The council is sponsoring a
series of six assemblies which will
be held
on
various Fridays
throughout the coming year.
Today's program Marked the
inauguration of the assembly
programs as Dr. Detlev W. Bronk
welcomed the students. A panel
et deans and professors were on
sand for a discussion of the future of Hopkins.
Snyder
believes
that
only
through greater co-operation between the students and the council can closer harmony between
the. faculty and the student body

Candidates
ert

(Continued from Page I)
Harris, Ike Powell, Carl

be secured.

Schwartzman, Torn

In order to facilitate this cooperation, the council has set up
a suggestion box, located at the
post office, which is available for
anyone who wishes to express his
own ideas or criticisms.

John Yakubisin.

It has long been recognized that
the traffic situation at Hopkins is
a grave problem. In order to remedy this situation as much as possible, the council has a Traffic
Committee headed
by Arnold
Peinado and assisted by Gene
Zemsky.
Peinado urgently requests that
all owners of cars on the campus
report this information to the
committee and receive parking
permits. This will help to alleviate a difficult problem.
Mone Margolis has been appointed to see what can be done
in order to make more used books
available to the students. The
council thinks there is much room
for improvement and hopes to get
a feasible plan working soon.
Last year's council made arrangements for most seniors to
not have to take final examinations.

During the ensuing six-week period there will probably be
a few infractions of the rushing agreement, and the matters will
be referred to the Interfraternity Board for adjustment. This
hoard, composed of representatives of the chapters, has power to
penalize for illegal rushing procedure. It is urged. that the
current IFB take all the steps necessary to function as a strong,
just organization. Weaknesses of the board reflect on all fraternity
men and hasty decisions, carelessness and disregard for its duty
to the fracternities and freshmen will surely result in serious
complications, and unnecessary ill feelings.
As a last reminder -to the freshmen: You have been told by
everyone who rushed and will rush you to look over all the groups.
These men mean what they say. Do it. Ask questions, any questions. If they cannot be answered satisfactorily, beware. But
there is one more thing that freshmen are. never told.
During rushing each fraternity gathers in the brothers like
a mother hen calls in her chicks. Everything is for the fraternity
and rightly so. However, when a freshman is pledged, especially
an out-of-town boy, it is sometimes urged that this group is the
only group and that his associations with other fraternities should
be limited. This is unfortunate and dangerous. True, the individual fraternities were tighter than drums during rushing.
!They had to be. But when rushing cools off, groups should begiii
to intermingle and friendships, undiscovered by the frosh during
rush season, should begin to pop everywhere.
So look the fraternities over, play the rushing game squarely,
pick the group with whom you want to associate for the next
four years, and remember that your choice, if made wisely, will
he ,the best.

Snyder Announces SC
Plans, Frosh Elections
Gil Snyder, president of the Student Council, has announced that
the freshman assembly originally
scheduled for Wednesday afternoon has been changed to Tuesday at four; but he emphasized
that the elections will still take
place on Thursday.
Snyder urges all freshmen to
attend the assembly, for the candidates running for offices will be
introduced at that time. They will
give short speeches.
Beside running the freshman
elections, the Student Council has
many other plans for the coming
year. The council is sponsoring a
series of six assemblies which will
be held
on
various Fridays
throughout the coming year.
Today's program Marked the
inauguration of the assembly
programs as Dr. Detlev W. Bronk
welcomed the students. A panel
et deans and professors were on
sand for a discussion of the future of Hopkins.
Snyder
believes
that
only
through greater co-operation between the students and the council can closer harmony between
the. faculty and the student body

Candidates
ert

(Continued from Page I)

be secured.

Schwartzman, Torn

In order to facilitate this cooperation, the council has set up
a suggestion box, located at the
post office, which is available for
anyone who wishes to express his
own ideas or criticisms.

John Yakubisin.

It has long been recognized that
the traffic situation at Hopkins is
a grave problem. In order to remedy this situation as much as possible, the council has a Traffic
Committee headed
by Arnold
Peinado and assisted by Gene
Zemsky.
Peinado urgently requests that
all owners of cars on the campus
report this information to the
committee and receive parking
permits. This will help to alleviate a difficult problem.
Mone Margolis has been appointed to see what can be done
in order to make more used books
available to the students. The
council thinks there is much room
for improvement and hopes to get
a feasible plan working soon.
Last year's council made arrangements for most seniors to
not have to take final examinations.

campus began their rushing of the freshman class.

of the brothers who graduated last June. To parents, friends,
faculty members, athletic coaches, residents in fraternity house
areas and others the whole rushing plan is a strenuous, nerveracking process.

During the ensuing six-week period there will probably be
a few infractions of the rushing agreement, and the matters will
be referred to the Interfraternity Board for adjustment. This
hoard, composed of representatives of the chapters, has power to
penalize for illegal rushing procedure. It is urged. that the
current IFB take all the steps necessary to function as a strong,
just organization. Weaknesses of the board reflect on all fraternity
men and hasty decisions, carelessness and disregard for its duty
to the fracternities and freshmen will surely result in serious
complications, and unnecessary ill feelings.
As a last reminder -to the freshmen: You have been told by
everyone who rushed and will rush you to look over all the groups.
These men mean what they say. Do it. Ask questions, any questions. If they cannot be answered satisfactorily, beware. But
there is one more thing that freshmen are. never told.
During rushing each fraternity gathers in the brothers like
a mother hen calls in her chicks. Everything is for the fraternity
and rightly so. However, when a freshman is pledged, especially
an out-of-town boy, it is sometimes urged that this group is the
only group and that his associations with other fraternities should
be limited. This is unfortunate and dangerous. True, the individual fraternities were tighter than drums during rushing.
!They had to be. But when rushing cools off, groups should begiii
to intermingle and friendships, undiscovered by the frosh during
rush season, should begin to pop everywhere.
So look the fraternities over, play the rushing game squarely,
pick the group with whom you want to associate for the next
four years, and remember that your choice, if made wisely, will
he ,the best.
